speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the lesions you're experiencing? How long have they been on your skin and have you noticed any changes in size, color, or texture?

speaker: Patient
text: They started about a month ago, and I've noticed they've been getting a bit bigger, the redness has turned into a crusty scab, and they're really itchy.

speaker: Doctor
text: How itchy have you been, would you say it's been constant or just on and off, and have you experienced any pain or discomfort while scratching these lesions?

speaker: Patient
text: It's been quite constant, to be honest, it's like my skin is on fire sometimes. And the pain is more of a burning sensation, especially at night, it keeps me awake. I've also had some difficulty sleeping because of the itching.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the location of these lesions on your body? Are they isolated to one area or are they scattered all over?

speaker: Patient
text: They're mainly on the shaft of my penis and on my left middle finger, but I've also noticed a similar lesion on my right index finger, it's like they're trying to tell me something, but I'm not sure what.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a closer look at the lesions on your penis and fingers. Can you please show me where they are exactly, and I'll examine them more thoroughly? Also, have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, fatigue, or weight loss, which could be related to an underlying infection or cancer?

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, let me show you exactly where they are. The lesion on my penis is about an inch long and about half an inch wide, and it's located right on the shaft, about halfway down. The one on my left middle finger is a bit smaller, about a quarter inch long and a quarter inch wide, and it's also on the shaft, near the tip. And, to answer your question, I haven't noticed any fever, fatigue, or weight loss, but I do feel like I've been getting more tired than usual lately."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the color and texture of the lesions? Are they flat or raised, and do they have any distinct edges or borders?

speaker: Patient
text: "They're more raised than flat, and they have a bit of a scabbed over surface, like the crusty part is trying to protect the underlying skin. As for the edges, they're not really distinct, it's just a bit of a rougher area around the lesion, but it's not like they're sharply defined or anything."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the scabbing on the lesions? Is it dry and flaky, or is it still moist and oozing? Also, have you tried any treatments or remedies for the lesions so far, such as over-the-counter creams or ointments?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, the scabbing is pretty dry and flaky, it's been cracking and crusting over for a while now. As for treatments, I've tried some local remedies in my home country, like applying plant extracts and herbal creams, but they didn't seem to work. I've also tried some over-the-counter creams and ointments here in the US, but nothing seems to be working, which is why I'm here."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a closer look at the lesions on your penis and fingers. Can you please remove your shirt and pants so I can examine them more thoroughly? Also, I'd like to request an imaging test to get a better look at the lesions. REQUEST TEST: High-Resolution Dermatology Ultrasound. Additionally, can you tell me more about the itching sensation? Is it constant or does it come and go? And have you noticed any changes in the color of the lesions over time?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital_Signs: Temperature: 36.8°C (98.2°F) Blood_Pressure: 130/85 mmHg Heart_Rate: 82 bpm Respiratory_Rate: 14 breaths/min Dermatological_Examination: Inspection: An erythematous plaque with areas of crusting, oozing, and irregular borders observed on the dorsal surface of the penile shaft and on the left middle finger. Palpation: Lesions are firm to touch, non-tender, with no warmth. Regional_Lymph_Nodes: No palpable cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy. tests: Biopsy: Findings: Cells with nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitotic figures within the follicle-bearing epithelium. STD_Panel: Syphilis: Negative HIV: Negative HBV: Negative HCV: Negative Imaging: High-Resolution Dermatology Ultrasound: NOT AVAILABLE (no data available) Itching Sensation: Constant, with worsening over the past week. Color Changes:
